You're LEGALLY entitled to compensation for flights canceled or delayed — Here's what you say:

Save this script to complain via email, chat, text, or phone:

"Hi, my name is [Your Name], and I'm reaching out to request compensation for my flight from [Origin] to [Destination] on [Date], which was [delayed/canceled]. I understand that flights can sometimes be delayed or canceled due to unforeseen circumstances, but I am entitled to compensation for the inconvenience caused by this [delay/cancellation].

I have attached copies of my ticket and any relevant receipts or documentation, including expenses for meals, accommodations, and transportation incurred due to the [delay/cancellation].

I would appreciate it if you could please review my case and provide me with a response as soon as possible.

Thank you for your attention to this matter."

When flights are canceled or delayed, you're legally entitled to:

• Refunds
• Alternate transportation
• Compensation for additional expenses
• Reimbursement for flight-related expenses

In the U.S., the Department of Transportation (DOT) requires airlines to compensate passengers for delays and cancellations. 

The DOT's rules do not specify an amount but require airlines to provide meals, accommodations, and transportation to and from the airport.

Under European Union (EU) regulations, if your flight is canceled or significantly delayed, you may be entitled to compensation from the airline if the delay or cancellation was within the airline's control.

The first thing you should do is contact the airline to determine your options.

• If your flight has been canceled, many airlines offer to either reschedule your flight later or provide a full refund for the ticket.

• If your flight has been delayed, many airlines offer compensation or assistance, such as meals or hotel accommodations, depending on the length of the delay and the circumstances.

If you experienced a significant delay or other inconvenience, you may be able to receive additional compensation to cover any additional expenses you incurred as a result.

If you cannot find a satisfactory resolution, you can file a complaint with the Department of Transportation.

You don't get what you deserve, you get what you negotiate.

And everything in life is negotiable.

If you want to get rich, here are 7 tips to master negotiation:
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

full_text:
1. The power of silence and pauses:

Awkward silences create pressure.

After making an offer, stop talking and wait for the other side to respond.

Silence prompts the other side to fill the void, sometimes making concessions.
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

full_text:
2. The 6 P's: 

Proper Prior Preparation Prevents Poor Performance. 

Master your facts and leverage points to negotiate effectively vs. making hurried concessions.
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

full_text:
3. Always ask for more:

Ask for more than you think you can get. 

This gives you room to compromise while still ending up with what you want.

Make a first offer that resets their sense of what's acceptable. Then, "concede" toward your actual goal.
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

full_text:
4. Odd numbers and precise figures: 

Odd numbers and unusual precision feel more carefully calculated.

Proposing $49,431 seems more grounded than $50,000.
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

full_text:
5. Have them negotiate against themselves:

Say, "This offer isn't where I need it to be. How can you improve upon it?" 

Get them thinking of better offers.
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

full_text:
6. Ask them to justify:

Put the burden of proof on them to substantiate.

“Can you walk me through your methodology for arriving at that number?"
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

full_text:
7. Positive framing:

People respond better to a positive approach.

Say what you want rather than what you don't want.
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

Hard truths I know in my 30s that I wish I knew in my 20s:

1. Start saving for retirement as soon as possible - small amounts add up over time thanks to compound interest.

2. Network and build connections early on - it will open up doors that a college degree cannot.

3. Never let work consume your entire life. Make time for your personal life and relationships.

4. Read more. Knowledge is power.

5. Time is your most valuable asset. Use it wisely; you can never get lost time back.

6. Don't be afraid of failure. You'll make mistakes; learn from them.

7. Don't compare yourself to others. Comparison is the thief of joy - focus on your path.

8. Not everyone will like you, and that's okay.

9. Say 'no' more often to protect your time and energy. You can't please everyone, so stop trying.

10. Most of your friends from your 20s don't stick around long-term. That's OK.

11. Spend more time with your family. You'll regret not doing it more.

12. You don't need to go to a prestigious school to be successful. Grades aren't everything.

13. Pick your spouse carefully. Wrong choices set you back years.

14. That toxic friend/partner? Cut them off sooner than later.

15. Don't wait for opportunities to come to you. Go out and create them.

Trump’s win will affect your money, taxes, and finances.

But what does it mean for you?

Here's everything you need to know:
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

full_text:
1. Taxes:

• One of Trump’s key tax proposals is to eliminate federal income taxes on tips, Social Security benefits, and overtime pay – which could provide financial relief for certain groups, but also reduce revenue for programs like Social Security.

• He has also promised to extend the individual and estate tax cuts from his 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, which are set to expire at the end of 2025.

• Trump’s overall tax plan is estimated to increase the deficit by $4.1 trillion over 10 years, according to analyses. The large tax cuts, especially for corporations and the wealthy, are expected to contribute to this.
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

full_text:
2. Stock Market:

• The initial market reaction to Trump’s victory was positive, with stocks rallying. Investors likely see his proposals for corporate tax cuts and deregulation as favorable for profits.

• However, his protectionist trade policies, including broad tariffs, could weigh on multinational companies and sectors like semiconductors, autos, and clean energy that are exposed to trade tensions.

• Bond yields are expected to rise further due to concerns about growing deficits from Trump’s economic agenda, which would hurt bond prices.

• Emerging markets could face headwinds from a strengthening dollar, higher US interest rates, and the potential for trade conflicts.
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

full_text:
3. Interest Rates:

• With Trump’s economic agenda potentially fueling higher inflation, the Federal Reserve would likely need to keep interest rates elevated to cool the economy.

• This would translate to higher borrowing costs for consumers, including on mortgages, auto loans, and credit cards. Mortgage rates could climb further from their current level above 7%.

• However, savers could benefit from higher yields on their deposits and other fixed-income investments.
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

full_text:
4. Housing:

• Trump has proposed measures aimed at increasing the housing supply, such as opening up more federal lands for development and reducing regulations.

• His plan to deport millions of immigrants could deepen housing affordability issues, as the construction industry relies heavily on immigrant labor.

• Trump has not unveiled detailed housing policies, and affordability would likely remain a key challenge given persistent supply shortages and high mortgage rates.
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

full_text:
5. Inflation:

• Trump has promised to “defeat” inflation, but economists say many of his policies could increase prices.

• His plan to impose sweeping tariffs on imports, including a 60% tariff on goods from China, would likely raise consumer prices on a wide range of products, such as clothes, appliances, and more.

• Deporting millions of undocumented immigrants could also drive up prices, especially in industries like construction that rely heavily on immigrant labor.

• Trump has said he would take steps to lower energy prices, such as increasing oil and gas production on federal lands. However, experts are skeptical this would have a major impact on gas prices, which are influenced more by global market forces.
name: Andrew Lokenauth | TheFinanceNewsletter.com

When borrowing money, keep your monthly loan payments below 40% of your income.

If you make $4,000 monthly, your total loan payments should stay under $1,600.

Banks use this rule because they know people who borrow more often run into trouble.
